items.title: N.L. Hydro lifts power warning, power watch in place
items.summary_auto: The power warning for residents across the island of Newfoundland is now lifted, according to a press release by Newfoundland and Labrador Hydro.

items.title: NBA players association voices support for Minnesota protesters
items.summary_auto: The National Basketball Players Association voiced support on Sunday for protesters in Minneapolis, rallying against the deadly presence of U.S. federal immigration authorities.

items.title: B.C. tourism agencies face off for a piece of Heated Rivalry star Hudson Williams
items.summary_auto: Hudson Williams, who stars as Shane Hollander in the Crave series, has connections to Vancouver, Kelowna, Kamloops and New Westminster. The cities' tourism bureaus are now leaning in to the success of the series with in a tongue-in-cheek competition on social media to claim the actor as their own.

items.title: How Minnesota's history of protest informs this moment
items.summary_auto: Minnesota has a robust history of protest going back to the 1890s, and the pivotal moments the twin cities played in labour and civil rights movements.

items.title: Canada names Olympic roster for luge, with 5 first-time Olympians
items.summary_auto: Canada has named its six athletes for the Olympic luge team, with five first-time Olympians set to hit the big stage.

items.title: GTA residents urged to 'stay home' during storm, as snow accumulation could reach 60 cm
items.summary_auto: As heavy snow falls throughout the Greater Toronto Area, here's what you need to know about the latest impacts to transit, flights and municipal services.

items.title: Canadian figure skater Fournier Beaudry discusses Sørensen sex assault allegation in Netflix doc
items.summary_auto: Figure skater Laurence Fournier Beaudry broke down in tears in a new Netflix documentary as she described being caught up in the fallout after Nikolaj Sørensen, her boyfriend and former ice dance partner, was accused of sexual assault.

items.title: Massive winter storm across U.S. brings snow, frigid temperatures, widespread power outages
items.summary_auto: Forecasters said snow, sleet, freezing rain and dangerously frigid temperatures would sweep the eastern two-thirds of the United States on Sunday and into the week.

items.title: Kyiv residents stranded in tower blocks as Russia targets power system
items.summary_auto: Kyiv, a city of about three million people, is dominated by tower blocks, many from the Soviet era, now left without power for most of the day. In this fourth winter of war, electricity is a rationed commodity.

items.title: How grocery giants control who can sell food in your neighbourhood: CBC's Marketplace cheat sheet
items.summary_auto: The CBC's Marketplace rounds up the consumer and health news you need from the week.

items.title: As U.S. ships move toward Mideast, Iranian general warns his force has ‘finger on the trigger’
items.summary_auto: Nournews, a news outlet close to Iran’s Supreme National Security Council, reported on its Telegram channel that the commander, Gen. Mohammad Pakpour, warned the United States and Israel "to avoid any miscalculation."

items.title: New Netflix series about a hockey team's bus crash hits a nerve in Sask.
items.summary_auto: A new Netflix hockey series is in production, set in a working-class town where hockey is everything until a bus crash kills players and their coach. The similarity to the Humboldt Broncos' tragedy is raising eyebrows in their home province.

items.title: Dingoes that circled Piper James's body on Australian beach to be culled
items.summary_auto: In an online statement, a spokesperson from the government's Ministry of Environment and Tourism said it was aware of initial autopsy findings suggesting dingo bites were likely not James's immediate cause of death.

items.title: Parks Canada shuttering Historic Places website, sparking heritage concerns
items.summary_auto: Parks Canada says it will deactivate the Canadian Register of Historic Places website this spring, leaving no alternative database to look up Nova Scotia heritage sites in one location.

items.title: Princess Charlotte showing more confidence in public appearances
items.summary_auto: As Princess Charlotte steps out in public with her family, the 10-year-old daughter of the Prince and Princess of Wales is starting to show increasing signs of independence and confidence.

items.title: When my son cried, I listened. My father never had that when he was in residential school
items.summary_auto: What started as a school drop-off turned into a deeply emotional moment for Alexander Redhead that connected to his late father’s experience in residential school — and to what it means to be an Indigenous parent trying to break cycles through love and compassion.

items.title: A Canada-run alternative to Nexus? Senator calls for new airport security fast-pass
items.summary_auto: With Canadian travel to the United States in decline, one Alberta senator says it's time for Ottawa to consider a Canadian-specific program that would allow travellers to quickly pass through airport security lines.

items.title: ICE nodding to far-right extremists in recruitment posts, experts say
items.summary_auto: In its efforts to rapidly boost its ranks, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement has been making appeals on social media in language familiar to right-wing extremists.

items.title: Canada's wildfire paradox: fewer fires, greater destruction highlighted in new analysis
items.summary_auto: A new national analysis finds Canada is seeing fewer wildfires overall, but a growing share of damage is being driven by a smaller number of increasingly large, hard-to-control fires.
